newsitem.title: USA: Fed refrains from open market operations.
newsitem.headline: Fed refrains from open market operations.

text.p: The Federal Reserve refrained from open market operations, as expected, during their usual intervention period on Friday.
The Fed injected reserves into the banking system on Thursday via five-day fixed system repurchase agreements.
Analysts interpreted Thursday's operation as an attempt by the central bank to provide the market with sufficient liquidity to span the long Memorial Day Holiday weekend.
By Tuesday, the Fed should get a more accurate estimate on currency demand over the holiday and will likely come in with multi-day day system RPs, analysts said.
With the add need growing in coming weeks, analysts said a permanent injection of reserves could come any time during this period via an outright purchase of bills or, less likely, a coupon pass.
The Fed has performed a bill pass within two weeks after Memorial Day for six of the last seven years, though the add need this year is not so large as to make one a sure bet, analysts said.
At midmorning on Friday, the federal funds rate was trading at 5-3/8 percent, below its 5-1/2 percent target rate.
